action.action-desc: Mr. Hill introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committees on Oversight and Reform, House Administration, and the Judiciary, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To regulate the posting of personal information of government officials on the internet, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Public Servant Protection Act of 2022.

section.header: Privacy of personal information of government officials

subparagraph.text: any officer or employee described in section 1114 of title 18 United States Code; and
any officer or employee of a State, a political subdivision of a State, or a Tribal government.

paragraph.text: The term immediate family member has the meaning given the term in section 115 of title 18, United States Code.
The term interactive computer service has the meaning given the term in section 230 of the Communications Act of 1934 (47 U.S.C. 230).

The term State means any State of the United States, the District of Columbia, the Commonwealth of Puerto Rico, the Virgin Islands, Guam, American Samoa, the Commonwealth of the Northern Mariana Islands, and any possession of the United States.
The term Tribal government has the meaning given the term Indian tribal government in section 102 of the Robert T. Stafford Disaster Relief and Emergency Assistance Act (42 U.S.C. 5122).

A government official may directly, or through an agent designated by the government official, make a written demand to a person to refrain from publicly displaying on the internet the personal information of the government official or an immediate family member of the government official.
If a government official makes a written demand to a person under paragraph (1), the person—

subparagraph.text: shall, not later than 48 hours after the receipt of the written demand, remove any personal information of the government official or an immediate family member of the government official displayed on the internet by the person; and

during the 4-year period following the date of the receipt of the written demand, may not publicly display on the internet the personal information of the government official or an immediate family member of the government official.

subsection.header: Written demand to interactive computer service providers

paragraph.text: A government official may directly, or through an agent designated by the government official, make a written demand to the provider of an interactive computer service to remove the personal information of the government official or an immediate family member of the government official that is publicly displayed on the interactive computer service.

If a government official makes a written demand to the provider of an interactive computer service under paragraph (1), the provider shall, not later than 48 hours after the receipt of the written demand, remove from the interactive computer service any personal information of the government official or an immediate family member of the government official that is publicly displayed on the interactive computer service.

A government official who is aggrieved by a violation of subsection (b)(2) or (c)(2) may bring a civil action against the person or the provider of an interactive computer service, respectively, that violated that subsection in an appropriate district court of the United States.
